text: a bunch of updates are now live in Yggdrasil: `HostBuildDependency`, new macOS SDK for M1, parallel compression with pigz.  I can confirm it's quite much faster, only concern is slightly larger size of artifacts, can be a real issue for CUDA

elements.text: a bunch of updates are now live in Yggdrasil:
, new macOS SDK for M1, parallel compression with pigz.  I can confirm it's quite much faster, only concern is slightly larger size of artifacts, can be a real issue for CUDA

text: <@U679T6QF7> I wonder if we should make `pigz` opt-in.  honestly, in Yggdrasil I prefer smaller tarballs to faster compression, for compiler shards the opposite

elements.text: I wonder if we should make
opt-in.  honestly, in Yggdrasil I prefer smaller tarballs to faster compression, for compiler shards the opposite

text: Switching to the `7z` file format will probably get us much smaller artifact size and faster compression than 7zip's `gzip` support. Just need to get Pkg support onboard. We can definitely make `pigz` opt-in. I can take a look at an old CUDA archive and check the difference

elements.text: file format will probably get us much smaller artifact size and faster compression than 7zip's
support. Just need to get Pkg support onboard. We can definitely make
opt-in. I can take a look at an old CUDA archive and check the difference

text: <https://github.com/JuliaBinaryWrappers/CUDA_full_jll.jl/releases/download/CUDA_full-v11.0.3%2B1/CUDA_full.v11.0.3.x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz> is 1.7GB
I'll run it again then. `pigz -11` was slightly smaller
`CUDA_full.v11.0.3.x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz` is 1.8GB with `pigz -9` gzip (14s), 1.8 GB with `pigz -11` (19m35s), 1.1GB with the 7z format (1m40s), and 1.1GB with xz format (2m8s)

elements.text: (19m35s), 1.1GB with the 7z format (1m40s), and 1.1GB with xz format (2m8s)

text: what about using `xz -9 -T 0`? It is also multithreaded, uses more or less the same algorithm as 7z and gives 1.1GB as well in about the same time. But it is a lot more widely used / preinstalled, e.g. for ubuntu, debian or fedora packages, which would make it easier to use outside of julia.

elements.text: ? It is also multithreaded, uses more or less the same algorithm as 7z and gives 1.1GB as well in about the same time. But it is a lot more widely used / preinstalled, e.g. for ubuntu, debian or fedora packages, which would make it easier to use outside of julia.

text: available memory: > 10 GB

I tried this:
```$ time bash -c 'cat CUDA_full.v11.0.3.x86_64-linux-gnu.tar | xz -9 -T 0 > cuda9.txz'

real    4m45.872s
user    57m30.409s
sys     1m12.186s```

$ time bash -c 'cat CUDA_full.v11.0.3.x86_64-linux-gnu.tar | xz -9 -T 0 > cuda9.txz'

real    4m45.872s
user    57m30.409s
sys     1m12.186s

text:
with the 3GB cuda tarball and 16 threads I got with 7z:
```real    5m21.724s
user    51m58.846s
sys     1m15.371s```
and with xz:
```real    4m31.993s
user    54m56.466s
sys     1m18.149s```
in this case xz was slightly better parallelized

text: That's good to know, thanks for the test! At this point probably I'd prefer using xz, at very least optionally, for example for the compiler shards, and maybe cuda. I'm still not sure it's a good idea to enable it for all tarballs, are we sure we can handle it everywhere (Windows being the usual suspect)?

elements.text: That's good to know, thanks for the test! At this point probably I'd prefer using xz, at very least optionally, for example for the compiler shards, and maybe cuda. I'm still not sure it's a good idea to enable it for all tarballs, are we sure we can handle it everywhere (Windows being the usual suspect)?

text: 7z has support for the format so I think we're in good shape
